content.description: This was originally a trad route, now it is fully bolted. It is a stellar dihedral/crack climb, one of the best of its grade in the area.
content.location: It ascends the huge dihedral on the far right side of the Elk Prow.

content.description: An early overhang leads to enjoyable, flowy climbing.
content.location: It is jeft, just around the corner from Bushwhacker crack.

climbs.name: Velociraptor
climbs.fa: Bill Gibson, Jeff Achey, Amber Johnstone

content.description:
Start on small horizontal ledges to the first bolt. Then follow a discontinuous crack system up changing corners. The technical crux is at a right-facing corner near the 4th bolt. About halfway up, continue by pulling over a bulge into a left-facing dihedral, and step out left on slab under another mini-bulge. The final slab is protected by 3 bolts to a corner with a layback crack and stemming to the anchor. The route is continuous and

LONG

but has 2-3 decent resting spots along the way. It is well-protected at the cruxes.
content.protection: 14 bolts, not including the anchor. The anchor has Fixe rings. Yes, it can be done with 60m rope.
content.location:
The route is on South-facing prow/buttress near the beginning of the Main Elk crag proper, kind of where Pup Tent ends and the Main Elk routes start. Its location is between T-Rex (right) and

Fried Lizard Gizzard

which is a left-facing, bolted, dihedral crack (left). Other routes routes nearby are

Patchouli

, Southern Fried Chicken, (to the West) and

Limp Lizards

, around the corner, (to the East).

There is a connector-trail made of rock steps (thanks, Brian G.) leading uphill to the buttress that forks right from the Main Elk canyon trail before entering the canyon.

The hike is about a 15-20 minute jaunt from the parking area.

content.description:
This is the left variation of

Big Kitty

. Do the same pumpy layback start as that route, then start heading left into the dihedral after the third bolt.

It is fun and pretty continuous. I didn't think there was an obvious crux on this one, just fairly sustained climbing. There are lots of laybacks and a couple jams and fingerlocks here and there.
content.location: These are the first routes left of the big overhangs on the Mutton Wall. Look for a big dihedral on the left bolt line that starts shortly after the third bolt.

content.description: Wow. Amazing addition by a local legend. Busting through the steepest part of the big roof in the superlative area, taking an obvious line of weakness that maybe only the boldest of choss wranglers would tackle, until you get up there and realize the rock actually quite good! Climb through the wild roof with memorable, satisfying movement in a crazy cool position with cool holds, try to shake and or clip(or neither) at a stance once the lip is pulled, then tech your way to the anchors pumped silly. Phenomenal route with a little bit of everything.
content.location: King line of the superlatives.

content.description:
This is an excellent variation to

Velociraptor

that throws in one more crux and continues up an overhanging, bottomless dihedral instead of the slab corner high on the route.

Climb the first 2/3rds of

Velociraptor

.  Right before getting established on the dark slab up high, make exciting moves right and into the steep dihedral for a few bolts before reaching a separate anchor at cliff top.
content.protection: 14 or 15 bolts; anchor with lowering biners.
content.location:
Use the same start as

Velociraptor

on the big prow as Main Elk.

content.description:
Climb the first 5 (crumbly) bolts of

Breathless

, then head up and right, and climb 11 more bolts up the vertical face. The face has many short cruxes and many mini-rests. It stays on you all the way to the top!
content.location:
Hike past the wall with all of the very short routes (including Dust Bunny and

Jewel Rosena

). The trail dips down after you pass

Pi

. Look up and right to see

Breathless

and Tierra del Libre.

content.description:
This is the King line of the Main Elk crag and the most difficult by assigned grade. The crux of this route climbs more like Rifle Canyon than Main Elk.

Climb up easy, intro rock for a few bolts before encountering some tricky, face climbing moves. A good rest presents itself part way up where you can hang out as long as needed. Leave the rest through another short crux, and get established on a decent shake below the imposing roof. From here, power and kneebar your way through the steep, tiered roof to a final finishing jug. Lower here to save your rope if working the route, or if sending, climb easier rock to an anchor just before the top of the cliff.

A left kneebar pad is helpful.

A 12b variation of this route "Baby Rex" climbs the lower face before breaking left to finish on "

Triceratops

". Don't follow these bolts which break left into the dihedral.
content.protection: 15 bolts to anchors. Rope drag can be a pain, so it is best to backclean or sling the first few bolts, and use a few long draws on the route.
content.location:
This climbs the obvious buttress just to the left of the approach trail. To the left is the shared start of the popular warm-ups "

Velociraptor

" & ""

Triceratops

". To the right is the obvious crack splitting the buttress "

Howl Roof

".

content.description: Start by rockaneering in a dirty, bushy corner up to the first bolt. Don't let first impressions scare you off at this point, because the rest of the climb is pretty great! Consistent edge pulling past the first 9 bolts brings on a good pump before you arrive at the crux above the 10th bolt. Keep it together, and fight to clip the chains!
content.location:
This is on the far left side of Main Elk crag; about 30 feet left of

Eight Days on the River

.

content.description: Spunky Monkey has cool, balancy moves sideways to a small roof.
content.location: Almost to the last section of beginner climbs, there is a shaded section, with a small roof. Spunky goes up the middle of the wall.

content.description:
This is best done as 2 pitches if you are climbing to the rim, the topmost anchor. The first 60' takes you to a nice ledge with two bolts, 10d. This section includes some funky moves in a groove/handcrack about 25' off the ground. Easier climbing leads to the ledge.

It is easy to continue up another 30 feet to an anchor at the lip of a roof, also 10d to this point. It is 30 meters to ground from this point. A funky groove to a stance below the roof is the crux of this section.

If you are interested in pulling the airy roof above and techy moves, which ups the grade to .11c, then I suggest bringing your belayer up the first 60 feet to the ledge. Lead up to and over the roof to an anchor at the rim. This is 130 feet to the ground I believe. The upper headwall is fun but suffers from seasonal dirt runoff, be forewarned.
content.protection: If you are climbing to below the roof in one pitch, I would bring 14 draws.
content.location:
This is the second route right of

Pi

. A left-facing corner leads up to an obvious groove. Climb a short handcrack, and up you go.

content.description: Ryan Goes to Hell is slabby with odd blocks. Watch for the bull snake at the 2nd bolt. The anchors are tucked onto the right, in the chimney.
content.location: Start left of a 15 choss ledge, and stay left of Bushwhacker crack.

climbs.name: Red Cap
climbs.fa: Bryan Gall, Dan O'meara, Paul Dudley, 2015

content.description:
Climb the arête up the slab.

This has rap rings at the top.
content.location: Look for the black slab at the far end of the trail.

content.description: Cruise through the low choss to a beautiful face of flakes and edges. Pumpy moves down low lead to some techy moves above. This is fairly continuous the entire time.
This climbs the obvious crack line through the bulge.  The crux is at the second roof, it is kind of a hard/strange clip on the bolt above the roof.
content.protection: Bolts and a [piton] at the top.
content.location:
This route is about 40 feet to the [left] of

Giblet Gravey

.

content.description: A crux on loose rock down low leads to left-trending stemming. Pull around the corner, and enjoy pleasant face climbing to the chains.
content.location: This route trends left up through a weakness on the right side of a large roof.

climbs.name: Mongrels
climbs.fa: Bill Gibson, Jeff Achey & Amber Johnstone

content.description: From the trail, walk uphill 20' to some ledges where you can belay. The first 15 feet of route is an off-hands to fingers crack (2 bolts). At the 3rd bolt, start a series of face moves over moderate bulges to small, horizontal ledges. It is fairly sustained for rating, but there are good stances in between clips. The last 10 feet to anchors is still a bit dusty but should improve over time with more ascents.
content.location:
This route is about 120 yards left (North) of '

Patchouli

' & 'Best in Show' and possibly 90 yards right (South)of 'Burning from Both Ends'. There are also 2 short bolted routes to the left of this route.

Look for a bolted face with a crack start. The anchors are on a black headwall 10' below a large ledge.

content.description: This is a decent trad route on the left side of the Main Elk Crag. Follow an open dihedral system with some stemming to a ledge with some loose rocks. Negotiate a headwall that is a bit steeper than it appears from the ground to the anchors. Watch for loose rocks and blocks that could become dislodged. There was one or two that looked a bit dangerous when I was here.
content.protection:
A rack of cams maybe with a few extras in the small to mid-sizes, nuts (the wired kind).

Per

BJ Sbarra

: this is now fully bolted.
content.location:
It is one of the farthest routes to the left at the Main Elk crag. From where the trail meets the rock, hike left along the base of the cliff until you reach the obvious crack.

If this route is your first objective, a more direct way to get there is to follow the creek trail past the usual turn to the Main Elk Crag until you see an obvious mushroom-shaped rock in the creek on the left. About twenty feet past this there is a good trail on the right that leads directly to this climb.

content.description: A couple of easier bolts leads to a short and physical crux that takes you to an undercling feature that's big enough to match. Do a delicate step left, and find some bigger holds out left to make this 12a. Apparently the original line stayed straight and went around 12c.
content.protection: 6 bolts and biners at the anchor.
content.location:
It is the furthest left line on the panel of rock just left of

Best in Show

and

Black Ball Retriever

. This shares an anchor with a 12+ or 13- just a few feet to the right called Walking the Dogs.

content.description:
Previously a mixed trad climb, it's now fully bolted, extended higher, and in my opinion one of the best 5.9s in Western Colorado.

Start up some broken rock that quickly leads to excellent dark brown stone. A short crux at the steep crack leads to interesting climbing all the way to the anchor.
content.location:
It is just right of

Giblet Gravy

, up the obvious crack/groove feature.

content.description:
This has fun, varied climbing. Start up the choss band with a few interesting opening moves, technique your way up the middle slab, and finish with a roof pull with great holds.

It felt a little spicy on lead in comparison with some of the other routes, but it is still perfectly safe.
content.location:
It is just left of

Mint Jelly

, the fully bolted crack, and just right of

Fleece Pocket

, the first route that goes up the roof proper at the Mutton Wall.

content.description:
Once a scary run-out lead, this route has now been re-bolted (with permission from the FA) for your clipping pleasure!  The rebolting effort has morphed this route into a great, fun, and challenging addition to Main Elk.

After getting through the loose choss band at the start (this is the only bad rock on the entire route and prevalent across all routes at Main Elk), climb fun, technical, golden limestone to the overhanging crux.  Decipher the crux moves, and you are rewarded with a great jug rest below the final black slab headwall.  Attention to your feet and a clear head will help you get through this headwall, which is littered with sharp rock, great sidepulls, and thin horizontal crimp rails that look like they came off your hangboard!
content.protection:
You need a 70 meter rope to get down from this climb!

14 bolts; anchor with lowering biners.  Long slings may be useful below the overhanging section to reduce rope drag above.
content.location:
This route starts in the middle of the east-facing panel of the tall overhanging buttress on the far right side of Main Elk crag.  It is 4 routes to the right of

Velociraptor

.

content.description:
This is an extension to the

Fried Lizard Gizzard

corner.

Climb past the anchors of that route up the corner to reach a rest ledge out left before continuing up the slightly overhanging face. There is a crux right off the ledge and kind of another crux near the top where you can either cut back left on the face or continue up the arete to the anchors.
content.location:
It is an extension to

Fried Lizzard Gizzard

just left of

Velociraptor

by the prow of Main Elk.

content.description: Leanie Meanie climbs totally interesting moves with impossible to grip white powder all over the rock. It looks so cool but is nothing but frustrating.
content.location: Just before the last section of the crag, with the short beginner routes, there are two climbs in the shade, that need a lot of cleaning up. Leany is the great right flake.

content.description: Joyful Journey has some awesome juggy moves down low to a roof crux.  A little kneebar trickery makes things much easier. This looks terrible but climbs like a Rifle classic.
content.location: It is the 3rd climb from the far right of Main Elk Crag. This is basically right in front of you at the top of the trail in the middle of the amphitheater.

content.description: Start from the ledge above the choss. Do some easier moves off the ledge up nice rock. It shares the first three bolts with "Jim's Palomino", the route to the right. It steepens into some pumpy moves to gain the large, right-facing flake/crack.

Jim's Palomino shares the first three bolts with

Jorts...

then breaks right into a flake system that leads to the first reachy/balancy crux that spits you onto a steep headwall. Attain the break in the wall, then work your way up through a bulge to reach another flake system. This thing stays on you the whole headwall. It is both technical and powerful.
content.location:
It is just right of

Jorts...

on the Insomnia Wall.

content.description: Carefully pull through the low choss band to the first bolt.  From here, big pulls to great incuts and big flat edges characterize this climb until you reach a hard pull from crimps to another great sidepull.  Mantle top-out to the anchors above the ledge.
content.location:
This climb is located about 50 feet right of

Eight Days on the River

.  It's the left of two sport climbs that are right next to each other.  Scramble from the trail up to a small ledge below the first bolt.

content.description: Climb up fun and somewhat chossy rock to the base of the roof, shake out, then pull an easy little boulder out and left to a stance and start the business, fun, technical somewhat runout climbing ensues. if you like standing on your feet and crimping then this thing is your rig.
content.location: Scramble up to the superlative ledge, right of castration station.

content.description: The bottom is a little R-rated as the 1st bolt is about 25' up past really chossy rock. I climbed up 5' and stick clipped it. The crux is exiting the offwidth squeeze roof and doing a couple campus moves to stand up on the ledge. It has an awesome finish! Howl after the send!
content.protection: Bring cams: 1-#0.4, 1-#0.5, 2-3 #0.75s, 4-#1s, 1-#2, 1-#3, draws/runners, 1 bolt, and 1 fixed nut.  There's actually non-big gear in that roof/squeeze!
content.location: On the middle of the main prow, this ascends the obvious crack to the roof.

content.description: Hold The Line is cryptic and more pumpy, after the slab, than it appears from the ground. The crux is moving past the last bolt to the anchor.
content.location:
This pitch starts on a ledge up and left of the start of Ryan Goes to Hell. Step up blocky terrain, and clip a bolt out left on the Ryan route. Climb a fun slab past 4 more bolts, and then fire up the vertical block feature above.

This is the line left of the obvious chimney, where

Clever Girl

is located. Great rock and fun moves get you past several more bolts to the crux moves to the anchor.

content.description: Start up Bushwhacker, a wide bolted crack for a few bolts. From a stance, climb up right through a bouldery overlap. This section is significantly harder than the remainder of the pitch. Finish with thoughtful movement to an anchor with lowering carabiners.
content.location:
Do the same start as

Hold On Loosely

, but break up and right after a few bolts.

content.description:
Start on Bushwhacker, now bolted (permission granted by Brian), and climb up the wide crack 50 feet to a stance in an alcove.

Clever Girl

continues up and left, but you want to climb the obvious crack like feature on the right. Several bolts take you to a cruxy move near the anchor.
content.protection: Bolts (around 10 protection bolts) and lowering carabiners at the anchor.
content.location: Start on the bolted Bushwhacker from a ledge about 20 feet above the trail.

content.description: Climb through the standard choss band, and climb juggy 5.11 for a long section. Get a good rest near the top of the wall where it begins to steepen. Climb some engaging moves for a few more bolts to a final scoop. Try to shake here before pulling the final cryptic and quite difficult boulder problem, past a final hard clip.
content.location:
This is climber's left of the classic "

Gigantor

".

content.description: Climb mostly cheatable OW moves to the top.
content.location:
This is the wide OW between Eight Days on the River and

Jewel Rosana

. Use the same anchors.

content.description: This is an exceptionally fun route. Some say it's Main Elks best route. It is certainly the best that I have done so far. Like many of the routes here, there is an initial chossy section, but once you're through it (it's not that bad), the climbing is just one groovy move after the next. There are multiple 5.11ish cruxes, right up the center of the wall. This is one of those routes that reminds me why I enjoy climbing.
content.location: It is left of Blue Angel and two routes left of the black arete.

content.description: There's a tricky slab section a little ways up, then it gets steeper with massive jugs where you need them.
content.location: This is the 5th route walking down to the Main Elk Crag from the Pup Tent of Solitude. It's the left of 3 routes on a face before the cliff turns the corner and faces west.

content.description: This route is llong with many cruxes. There is one good rest at about 1/2 height, then it is very sustained through about 6 bolts of hard climbing. You get a decent rest before final steep bit, then make a few more punchy moves to easier climbing to the anchor. It climbs much more friendly with a few draws extended. The guidebook says it is 90 feet, but it seems longer than that. Watch your rope with a 60m to be safe.
content.location: This is on the right side of the Main Elk Crag prow just right of the large offwidth slot.

content.description:
This fun, short route climbs the clean-looking finger crack in the left-facing corner.

Start by climbing up the chossy choss band, which fortunately is well protected by bolts.  Gain a stance below the crack, clip a bolt, and jam/stem/lieback your way through the bulge to a good stance above.  A few more easy moves gains the anchors.
content.location:
This route is located on the left side of the huge buttress as you enter Main Elk from Pup Tent.  It is the next route left of

Velociraptor

.

content.description:
This is the 3 bolt extension to

Fresh Fried Chicken

with a crux near the top. This adds quality to the pitch: an extra star? and some difficulty or an extra letter? Thanks to the FA’er(s)!
content.protection: 3 more draws. It has carabiners at the anchor.
content.location:
Climb

Fresh Fried Chicken

, then keep going.

content.description:
The crux is pulling over the roof about 20 feet up. It is 10a to the first anchor, and the extension ups the grade to 11c/d.

After the roof, move up and right into a nice, short, right-facing corner. The climbing eases dramatically after the roof pull.
content.protection: 12 draws will get you to the first anchor, bring another 5 for the extension.
content.location: The route starts down and right of the Jorts ledge.  There is a flat spot in the trail, same location as the start of Virgin Wool.  Virgin Wool is the left line of bolts and Freshly Squeezed is the line of bolts veering up and right.

content.description: After the standard Main Elk choss start, pull the overhang, and get established above the roof. Clipping the second bolt is quite tricky, consider a stickclip. Once above the overhang, get some good holds and cruise to the anchors. Use caution at the anchors as the rock begins to deteriorate.
content.location:
At the far end of the Main Elk Crag, start just left of two new routes under a sharp arete feature. To the left is "

Big Kitty

," to the right is "

Bladerunner

".

content.description: Start out on easy slabby blocky stair step climbing.  Then move to a roof.  Pulling the roof and getting a good stance is probably the crux.  The black rock above the roof is very beautiful and fun to climb on.
content.protection: There are 8 bolts to Metolius anchors.
content.location: The route is the third from the right.

content.description: Start up the standard choss band, and pull the low roof. Traverse powerfully left on good holds, and continue up to easier ground. A nice rest presents itself before the final roof, which can be overcome on good-size jugs.
content.location: On the Mutton Wall at the far end of the wall, start on the right side of the small cave. To the right is "Mary Had A Little Lamb", and to the left is "Aries".

content.description: This is one of the steepest routes at Main Elk. You might feel like you're climbing at Rifle as you kick your feet around in space and crank long pulls on big, blocky holds. The movement is fantastic. The main thing this route suffers from is lack of traffic, which is why I'm posting it here. It sits below a runoff zone and is prone to collecting dirt if it goes unused for too long. If it cleans up it might feel more like honest 12c (the "12c/d" rating is how it's listed in the guidebook) and be the kind of pitch I would climb again and again. The dirt factor at the top makes it a touch harder, though.
content.protection: 11 bolts. Two or three long slings/draws are useful.
content.location: This is the rightmost route in the alcove, which is the zone just right of the prow, directly above the approach trail.

climbs.name: Ent Killer
climbs.fa: Bryan Gall, Dan O'Meara, Paul Dudley, 2015

content.description: Climb up the middle of the black slab past a definite crux.
content.location: Look for the black slab at the far end of the trail.

content.description: Start on blocky climbing to a roof.  Pulling the roof is not bad. Continue up the face and start climbing the arete.  Around the second to last bolt is the crux, kind of a awkward move on the arete.
content.location: The route is near a big dihedral with a roof.

content.description:
This mini-route offers good challenge in its short length. Pull fun bouldery moves past the initial bulge, and tip toe up the engaging slab to the anchors.

With some more brushing, chalk, and traffic, this climb could become quite popular for people looking for a good, short, bouldery 12a.
content.location: Around the corner from the blunt arete with the classic "Best In Show"  on the next sector.  To the left of this climb is the long crack splitting the wall "Old Skool".  To the right is "Mongrels".

content.description: Down On The Corner has fun and featured climbing in the right-facing corner. It is 5.9 to the first anchor and is protected by 7 bolts. Then it is 5.11a/b to the second anchor and is protected by 3 additional bolts.
content.protection: Bolts - 7 to the first anchor and 3 more to the upper anchor.
content.location:
Start just left of

Pi

in the obvious, right-facing corner.

content.description: There are a couple tricky moves in the bottom half of the climb, the upper half is easier but fun. It is a good choice for a warm-up lap.
content.location:
This is on the Main Elk prow just left of

Giblet Gravy

.

content.description:
This has easy slab to fun chimney climbing; squirm or stem to steep laybacking. This pitch allows you to use a variety of techniques and climbs to the top of the cliff in this section.

An airy finish adds to the fun!
content.protection: 15 draws will get you through.  There is a belay bolt on the ledge.
content.location:
Start the same as

Hold The Line

. Climb the slab, and clip a fixed draw in the chimney, then fire up the chimney. Stem it, grovel it, your call, but fun movement leads to a quick, pumpy, layback move onto a big stance on the left. You are standing just above the

Hold the Line

anchors now.

Stand up to some undercling moves, and then layback past 3 more bolts to the anchor.

content.description:
Tricky climbing for the first few bolts utilizing sidepulls and fingerlocks in a steep groove system leads to a fun crack switch and enjoyable face climbing to the anchors.

It's nice to stick clip the second bolt, so your belayer can belay down the hill a little and not up on the ledge.
content.location:
Start in a left-facing corner on the

Godzilla

sector three routes left of the classic

Gigantor

. To the right is Thundercat, to the left is Krakatoa. It is difficult to see the bolts until you're close to the wall.

content.description: Castration Station has cruxy moves throughout with poor foot holds in spots for super fun, sustained climbing. Watch out for some slippery rock at like the 4th or 5th bolt.
content.location: It is on the left side of a terrace with several climbs in the same zone as Eternal Flame.

content.description: This has fun climbing up a relatively steep corner system. One tricky move down low, but the true crux is the mandatory laybacking up high.
content.location: This is the somewhat obvious chalked up corner / crack system on the far left side of the Mutton Wall. There is at least one bolted route to the left of this climb that looks fairly difficult and doesn't look like it gets much traffic.

content.description:
Start on some choss. Once you get through that and onto the black slab, it gets good. Climb the slab moves just right of the arete. Once through the black slabby section, the climbing gets easier.

This is a fun route if you can ignore the initial band of choss. Definitely bring your 70m rope for this one.
content.location: It is on the black arete.

climbs.name: Bottom Feeder
climbs.fa: John VanNostrand Jr. and Gabe Collins, 2014

content.description: Start off the Insomnia Ledge, and climb up a steep, black-colored face that is split halfway by a ledge. There are a few large pulls below the ledge, but most of the business comes above on mostly large holds with a few slopers thrown in there. Don't let the pump get you!
content.location:
This is just left of

Jorts are the New Lyrica

on the Insomnia Wall ledge.

content.description: This has easy climbing up to an exposed move around an overhanging arete. Bolts follow the arete.
content.location:
Start in the corner under the arete at the far left of the cave where you find

Baa, Baa, Black Sheep

. Follow the obvious, overhanging arete. This line is the one to the right of

Freshly Shorn

.

content.description:
This is, bar none, one of the best routes at Main Elk.  After the initial choss band, the rock on this route is absolutely bullet.

Stick clip the first high bolt and move up and left to the left side of the large blocky nose feature ('Best in Show' climbs up the right side of this block and shares a rest jug at the top).  From the top of the block, bust left on crimpy and airy climbing to a powerful crux sequence which eventually gives way to larger holds and the anchor.
content.location:
This route is located about 20 yards left of '

Patchouli

', just around the corner.  It can be identified by the black bolt hangers and the blocky nose feature described above.

content.description: Bizzler has easy climbing to a right traverse. Bust up the arête feature to a stance, then head dead left on funky crimpers to a jug. Grab some holds, and jump to a jug. Finish with easier climbing to the top.
content.location:
This shares the same first bolt as

Best in Show

then trends right.

content.description:
Bighorn is a bit of a squeezed route, but it seemed to climb independently of the routes on either side.

Pull the initial bulge (about 11a?). Then find fairly easy climbing to about the 3rd or 4th bolt. Move left a few moves when the route seems to join

Velcro Glove

. Finish with sustained crimping and sidepulling to the anchor. There are two crux sections with interesting and fun moves. It looks blank above as you're climbing, but keep moving, and holds will appear.
content.protection: About 10 bolts, this has lowering carabiners at the anchor.
content.location:
This is between

Velcro Glove

and

Buggery

on the left side of Mutton Wall.

content.description: Layback a strenuous flake, then move right across a pleasant face with one hard move past a little roof. Steep, flowy climbing with ample holds makes this a popular warm-up.

Pass 2 bolts worth of less than ideal rock, then pass a short .12a crux to a rest. Faceclimb a beautiful headwall on small crimps, edges, and sidepulls with a few dynamic moves for 4 bolts. The headwall is the crux. This has sustained climbing to an easier top-out. This is a totally awesome route - best on the wall!
content.protection: 7 bolts; chain anchor with lower biners
content.location:
This is on Main Elk on the prow, just right of

Black Ball Receiver

.  The start is shared with The Bizzler (11+) and then goes straight up the overhanging headwall.

content.description:
This rarely traveled line is well worth climbing. While a bit sandbagged with a difficult devious crux, the rock is good, and the moves are quite fun.

After negotiating the initial choss band, climb up and negotiate the powerful, technical crux.  Get a good finger slot, clip the 4th bolt, and climb fun 11+ rock to the anchor.
content.location:
Start just left of the classic "

Black Ball Retriever

."

content.description:
Pull powerful moves through the low roof up to a cool, tufa-esque pinch. Pull over the roof to the third clip and a few more big moves to easier ground above. After a nice rest, continue up easy ground through cool rock formations and a few challenging moves as you traverse rightwards. Pull the final roof, and climb up the tenuous slab to the anchors. The line wanders quite a bit, so long draws are nice on the 2nd, 6th, and 7th bolts.

There appears to be a variation halfway up that traverses into the finish for "Big Kitty".

This is probably on the lower end of 12b.
content.protection: 10 bolts to anchors. If not solid at the grade, consider stick clipping or hanging a long draw on the third bolt.
content.location: It is on the Mutton Wall on the left side of the wall.

content.description: Pull a roof on underclings right at the start (the crux), then make your way through moderate climbing to a bulge. Once over the bulge, a fun, right-facing flake puts you at the anchors on top of the route.
content.location:
It is to the left of

Fleece Pocket

and

Mary Had a Little Lamb

.
